original: Majjhima Nikāya 91
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Brahmāyusutta
analyzed: brahmāyusutta
translated: With Brahmāyu

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā videhesu cārikaṁ carati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.🔽Tena kho pana samayena brahmāyu brāhmaṇo mithilāyaṁ paṭivasati jiṇṇo vuḍḍho mahallako🔽addhagato vayoanuppatto, vīsavassasatiko jātiyā, tiṇṇaṁ vedānaṁ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṁ
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā videhesu cārikam carati mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi  tena khalu pana samayena brahmāyuḥ brāhmaṇaḥ mithilāyam paṭivasati jiṇṇaḥ vuḍḍhaḥ mahallakaḥ  addha gataḥ vayaḥ anuppattaḥ vīsa vassa satikaḥ jātiyā tiṇṇam vedānam pāragū sa nighaṇḍu keṭubhāna
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was wandering in the country of the Videhans with a large Saṅgha of bhikkhus, with five hundred bhikkhus.

original: sākkharappabhedānaṁ itihāsapañcamānaṁ, padako, veyyākaraṇo, lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo.
analyzed: itihāsa pañcamānaṃ padakaḥ veyyākaraṇaḥ lokāyata mahāpurisa lakkhaṇesu anavayaḥ
translated: Now on that occasion the brahmin Brahmāyu was living at Mithilā. He was old, aged, burdened with years, advanced in life, and come to the last stage; he was in his hundred and twentieth year. He was a master of the Three Vedas with their vocabularies, liturgy, phonology, and etymology, and the histories as a fifth; skilled in philology and grammar, he was fully versed in natural philosophy and in the marks of a Great Man.

original: Assosi kho brahmāyu brāhmaṇo:
analyzed: assa asi kho brahmāyu brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: The brahmin Brahmāyu heard say:

original: “samaṇo khalu bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito videhesu cārikaṁ carati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
analyzed: samaṇaḥ khalu bho gotamaḥ sakya putto sakya kulā pabbajitaḥ videhesu cārikam carati mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi
translated: “The recluse Gotama, the son of the Sakyans who went forth from a Sakyan clan, is wandering in the country of the Videhans with a large Saṅgha of bhikkhus, with five hundred bhikkhus.

original: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
analyzed: tam kha pana bhavantam gotamam evam kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ
translated: Now a good report of Master Gotama has been spread to this effect:

original: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
analyzed: iti pi saḥ bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampanno sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā ati
translated: ‘This Blessed Lord is an Arahant, a fully-enlightened Buddha, endowed with wisdom and conduct, the Well-Farer, Knower of the worlds, incomparable Trainer of men to be tamed, Teacher of gods and humans, the Buddha, the Blessed Lord.’

original: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
analyzed: saḥ imam lokam sa devakam sa mārakam sa brahmakam sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇim pajam sa deva manussam sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti
translated: He reveals this world — with its gods, maras, Brahmas, the generation with its ascetics and Brahmins, its gods and humans — having come to know it by his own knowledge.

original: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
analyzed: saḥ dhammam deseti ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam sa attham sa byañjana kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāseti
translated: He teaches the Dhamma which is lovely in its beginning, lovely in its middle, and lovely in its ending, in the spirit and in the letter, and he displays the fully- perfected and purified holy life.

original: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī”ti.
analyzed: sādhu kho pana tathārūpānam arahatam dassanam hoti iti
translated: It is good to see such Arahants.”

original: Tena kho pana samayena brahmāyussa brāhmaṇassa uttaro nāma māṇavo antevāsī hoti tiṇṇaṁ🔽vedānaṁ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṁ sākkharappabhedānaṁ itihāsapañcamānaṁ, padako,
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena brahmāyussa brāhmaṇassa uttaraḥ nāma māṇavaḥ antevāsī hoti  vedānam pāragū sa nighaṇḍu keṭubhānam itihāsa pañcamānam
translated: Now at that time a young brahmin called Uttara, the pupil of the brahmin Brahmayu, was living at Kasi in Benares.

original: veyyākaraṇo, lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo.
analyzed: veyyākaraṇaḥ lokāyata mahāpurisa lakkhaṇesu anavayaḥ
translated: He was skilled in the mantras and expert in all the Vedas, in phonology, in grammar, in the lore of the signs and in the science of the cosmogony, and he knew the eighteen branches of knowledge.

original: Atha kho brahmāyu brāhmaṇo uttaraṁ māṇavaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: atha khalu brahmāyuḥ brāhmaṇaḥ uttaram māṇavam āmantesi
translated: He then told Uttara:

original: “ayaṁ, tāta uttara, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito videhesu cārikaṁ carati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
analyzed: tāta uttara samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ sakya putto sakya kulā pabbajitaḥ videhesu cārikam carati mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi
translated: “Uttara, the ascetic Gotama, the son of the Sakyans who went forth from the Sakyan clan, has been wandering in the lands of the Videhans with a large Sangha of five hundred monks.

original: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
analyzed: tam kha pana bhavantam gotamam evam kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ
translated: This is the kind of fine reputation he has:

original: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho …pe…
analyzed: saḥ bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ pe
translated: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, a Well-gone One, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed trainer of those who can be trained, a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha, a Blessed One.

original: sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī’ti.
analyzed: sādhu kho pana tathārūpānam arahatam dassanam hoti iti
translated: It’s good to see such perfected ones.’

original: Ehi tvaṁ, tāta uttara, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ jānāhi, yadi vā taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ tathā santaṁyeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vā no tathā;🔽yadi vā so bhavaṁ gotamo tādiso, yadi vā na tādiso.
analyzed: ehi tva tāta uttara yena samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ tena upasaṅkama upasaṅkamitvā samaṇam gotamam jānāhi yadi vā tam bhavantam gotamam tathā santayā iva saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ yadi vā no tathā  yadi vā saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ tādisaḥ yadi vā na tādisaḥ
translated: Come, Uttara, go to the ascetic Gotama and find out whether he really is so or not.

original: Tathā mayaṁ taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ vedissāmā”ti.
analyzed: tathā mayam tam bhavantam gotamam vedissāma ati
translated: Whether the ascetic Gotama is like that or not, we’ll know when we see him.”

original: “Yathā kathaṁ panāhaṁ, bho, taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ jānissāmi yadi vā taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ tathā santaṁyeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vā no tathā;
analyzed: yathā katham pana āha bho tam bhavantam gotamam jānissāmi yadi vā tam bhavantam gotamam tathā santayā iva saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ yadi vā no tathā
translated: “But how can I know whether the Lord Buddha is as people say he is, or whether he is not?

original: yadi vā so bhavaṁ gotamo tādiso, yadi vā na tādiso”ti.
analyzed: yadi vā saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ tādisaḥ yadi vā na tādisaḥ iti
translated: How can I know whether he is such as he is reported to be, or whether he is not?”🔽“My dear Uttara, in our books we find that there are thirty-two marks of a Great Man.

original: “Āgatāni kho, tāta uttara, amhākaṁ mantesu dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveyeva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
analyzed: āgatāni kho tāta uttara amhākam mantesu dvattisa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveyā iva gatiyaḥ bhavanti anaññā
translated: If he has these marks, one of two fruits can be expected of him:

original: Sace agāraṁ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
analyzed: sace agāram ajjhāvasati rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammikaḥ dhamma rājā cāturantaḥ vijitāvī janapadatthāvariya ppatto satta ratana samannāgato
translated: if he lives the home life he will become a ruler, a wheel-turning righteous monarch of the law, who keeps the four quarters secure with the Dhamma, and who possesses the seven treasures.

original: Tassimāni satta ratanāni bhavanti, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: tassa imāni satta ratanāni bhavanti
translated: These are the seven treasures:

original: cakkaratanaṁ, hatthiratanaṁ, assaratanaṁ, maṇiratanaṁ, itthiratanaṁ, gahapatiratanaṁ, pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
analyzed: cakka ratana hatthi ratana assa ratana maṇi ratana itthi ratana gahapati ratana pariṇāyaka ratanam eva sattama
translated: the wheel-treasure, the elephant-treasure, the horse-treasure, the jewel-treasure, the woman-treasure, the steward-treasure, and the counsellor-treasure as the seventh.

original: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
analyzed: parosahassam kho panassa puttāḥ bhavanti sūrāḥ vīraṅga rūpāḥ para sena ppamaddanāḥ
translated: He has more than a thousand sons who are heroes, powerful, and crush the armies of others.

original: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
analyzed: saḥ imam pathavim sāgara pariyantam a daṇḍena a satthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati
translated: He rules over this land that extends as far as the ocean, having conquered it by the Dhamma, without stick or sword.

original: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati, arahaṁ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
analyzed: sace kho pana agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajati araham hoti sammāsambuddhaḥ loke vivaṭṭa chadaḥ
translated: But if he goes forth from the home life into homelessness, he becomes an Accomplished One, a Fully Enlightened One, who draws aside the veil in the world.

original: Ahaṁ kho pana, tāta uttara, mantānaṁ dātā;
analyzed: aham khalu pana tāta uttara mantānam dātā
translated: I, dear Uttara, am the giver of the mantras,

original: tvaṁ mantānaṁ paṭiggahetā”ti.
analyzed: tvam mantānam paṭiggaheta ati
translated: and you are the receiver of the mantras.”

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho uttaro māṇavo brahmāyussa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā brahmāyuṁ brāhmaṇaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā videhesu yena bhagavā tena cārikaṁ pakkāmi.
analyzed: eva bhoti kho uttaraḥ māṇavaḥ brahmāyussa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāya āsanā brahmāyum brāhmaṇam abhivādetvā padakkhiṇam katvā videhesu yena bhagavā tena cārikam pakkāmi
translated: “Yes, sir,” the student Uttara replied. He got up from his seat, bowed down to the brahmin Brahmāyus, circumambulated him, and left for the country of the Videhans.

original: Anupubbena cārikaṁ caramāno yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.🔽Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: anupubbena cārikam caramānaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodi 🔽sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: When he eventually arrived, he went to see the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, he sat down to one side.

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho uttaro māṇavo bhagavato kāye dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni samannesi.🔽Addasā kho uttaro māṇavo bhagavato kāye dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yebhuyyena thapetvā dve.
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho uttaraḥ māṇavaḥ bhagavato kāye dvattisa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni samannesi  addasā kho uttaraḥ māṇavaḥ bhagavato kāye dvattisa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena thapetvā dve
translated: and he examined the Buddha’s body for the thirty-two marks of a great man.🔽He saw all of them except for two.

original: Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati—
analyzed: dvīsu mahāpurisa lakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati na adhimuccati na sampasīdati
translated: He was unsure of and undecided about two of the marks of a great man,

original: kosohite ca vatthaguyhe pahūtajivhatāya ca.
analyzed: ca vattha guyhe pahūta jivha tāya ca
translated: the male organ being enclosed in a sheath and the long tongue.🔽The Buddha read his mind

original: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavataḥ
translated: and he thought,

original: “passati kho me ayaṁ uttaro māṇavo dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yebhuyyena thapetvā dve.
analyzed: passati kho me ayam uttaraḥ māṇavaḥ dvattisa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena thapetvā dve
translated: “This brahmin student sees all the marks of a great man except for two.

original: Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati—
analyzed: dvīsu mahāpurisa lakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati na adhimuccati na sampasīdati
translated: He’s unsure of and undecided about two of the marks of a great man,

original: kosohite ca vatthaguyhe pahūtajivhatāya cā”ti.
analyzed: kosohite ca vattha guyhe pahūta jivha tāya ca ati
translated: the male organ being enclosed in a sheath and the long tongue.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā tathārūpaṁ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkhāsi yathā addasa uttaro māṇavo bhagavato kosohitaṁ vatthaguyhaṁ.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā tathārūpam iddha abhisaṅkhāram abhisaṅkhāsi yathā addasaḥ uttaraḥ māṇavaḥ bhagavataḥ kosohitam
translated: And the Buddha performed a feat of supernormal power such that Uttara saw the Buddha’s male organ being enclosed in a sheath.

original: Atha kho bhagavā jivhaṁ ninnāmetvā ubhopi kaṇṇasotāni anumasi paṭimasi; ubhopi nāsikasotāni anumasi paṭimasi; kevalampi nalāṭamaṇḍalaṁ jivhāya chādesi.🔽Atha kho uttarassa māṇavassa etadahosi:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavā jivham ninnāmetvā ubho api kaṇṇa sotāni anumasi paṭimasi ubho api nāsika sotāni anumasi paṭimasi kevalam pi nalāṭa maṇḍalam jivhāya chādesi  atha kho uttarassa māṇavassa etat ahosi
translated: He then extended his tongue, and starting from the right ear, he caressed and stroked the tip of his nose with his tongue.

original: “samannāgato kho samaṇo gotamo dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi.
analyzed: samannāgataḥ kho samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ dvattisa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇehi
translated: The thought occurred to him, “The contemplative Gotama is endowed with the thirty-two marks of a Great Man.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ anubandheyyaṁ, iriyāpathamassa passeyyan”ti.🔽Atha kho uttaro māṇavo sattamāsāni bhagavantaṁ anubandhi chāyāva anapāyinī.
analyzed: yat nūna aham samaṇam gotamam anubandheyya iriyāpatham assa passeyyanti  atha kho uttaraḥ māṇavaḥ satta māsāni bhagavantam chāyā ava anapāyinī
translated: What if I were to follow the contemplative Gotama and watch for his death? ”🔽So for seven months Uttara followed the Blessed One, like a shadow following a form, never leaving him.

original: Atha kho uttaro māṇavo sattannaṁ māsānaṁ accayena videhesu yena mithilā tena cārikaṁ pakkāmi.🔽Anupubbena cārikaṁ caramāno yena mithilā yena brahmāyu brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: atha kho uttaraḥ māṇavaḥ sattannam māsānam accayena videhesu yena mithilā tena cārikam pakkāmi  anupubbena cārikam caramānaḥ yena mithilā yena brahmāyu brāhmaṇaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā
translated: Then, after seven months had passed, he set out wandering among the Videhans,🔽eventually arriving at Mithila, where he went to live in the jungle thicket at the edge of the town.

original: brahmāyuṁ brāhmaṇaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho uttaraṁ
analyzed: brahmāyum brāhmaṇam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnam kho uttara
translated: He went to the brahman Brahmáyu, bowed down to him, and sat to one side.

original: māṇavaṁ brahmāyu brāhmaṇo etadavoca:
analyzed: māṇavam brahmāyu brāhmaṇaḥ etat avoca
translated: and said to him:

original: “kacci, tāta uttara, taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ tathā santaṁyeva saddo abbhuggato, no aññathā?
analyzed: kacci tāta uttara tam bhavantam gotamam tathā santayā iva saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ no aññathā
translated: “My dear Uttara, is the report about Master Gotama true, or is it false?

original: Kacci pana so bhavaṁ gotamo tādiso, no aññādiso”ti?🔽“Tathā santaṁyeva, bho, taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saddo abbhuggato, no aññathā;
analyzed: kacci pana saḥ bhavam gotamo tādisaḥ no aññādiso ti  tathā santayā iva bho tam bhavantam gotamam saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ no aññathā
translated: Is he like that, or is he otherwise?”🔽“The report about Master Gotama is true, not false.

original: tādisova so bhavaṁ gotamo, no aññādiso.
analyzed: tādisaḥ iva saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ no aññādiso
translated: He is like that, not otherwise.

original: Samannāgato ca so bhavaṁ gotamo dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi.
analyzed: samannāgataḥ ca saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ dvattisa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇehi
translated: Master Gotama is endowed with the thirty-two marks of a Great Man.

original: Suppatiṭṭhitapādo kho pana bho bhavaṁ gotamo;
analyzed: su patiṭṭhita pādaḥ kho pana bho bhavam gotamaḥ
translated: His feet are placed down well—

original: idampi tassa bhoto gotamassa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṁ bhavati.🔽Heṭṭhā kho pana tassa bhoto gotamassa pādatalesu cakkāni jātāni sahassārāni sanemikāni sanābhikāni sabbākāraparipūrāni …🔽Āyatapaṇhi kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo …
analyzed: idam pi tassa bhoto gotamassa mahā purisassa mahā purisa lakkhaṇam bhavati  heṭṭhā kho pana tassa bhoto gotamassa pāda talesu cakkāni jātāni sahassārāni sa nemikāni sa nābhikāni sabba ākāra paripūrāni  āyata paṇhi khalu pana saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ
translated: this is a mark of a Great Man.🔽On the soles of his feet there are wheels with a thousand spokes—🔽he has long fingers and toes—

original: Dīghaṅguli kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo …
analyzed: khaḥ pana saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ
translated: he has broad and arched feet—

original: Mudutalunahatthapādo kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo …🔽Jālahatthapādo kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo …
analyzed: kho pana saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ  jālahatthapādaḥ kho pana saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ
translated: His hands and feet are soft and tender …

original: Ussaṅkhapādo kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo …
analyzed: ussaṅkhapādaḥ kho pana saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ
translated: His hands and feet are webbed …🔽He has projecting heels …

original: Eṇijaṅgho kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo …
analyzed: eṇijaṅghaḥ khalu pana saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ
translated: He has long fingers and toes …

original: Ṭhitako kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo anonamanto ubhohi pāṇitalehi jaṇṇukāni parimasati parimajjati …🔽Kosohitavatthaguyho kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo …🔽Suvaṇṇavaṇṇo kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo kañcanasannibhattaco …

original: Cattālīsadanto kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo …🔽Samadanto kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo …🔽Aviraḷadanto kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo …

original: Gacchanto kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo dakkhiṇeneva pādena paṭhamaṁ pakkamati.
analyzed: gacchantaḥ kho pana saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ dakkhiṇena iva pādena paṭhamam pakkamati

original: So nātidūre pādaṁ uddharati, nāccāsanne pādaṁ nikkhipati;🔽so nātisīghaṁ gacchati, nātisaṇikaṁ gacchati;

original: Apalokento kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo sabbakāyeneva apaloketi;

translated: He receives neither too little nor too much rice.

original: Byañjanaṁ kho pana bhavaṁ gotamo byañjanamattāya āhāreti, na ca byañjanena ālopaṁ atināmeti.
analyzed: byañjanam khalu pana bhavam gotamaḥ byañjana mattāya āhāra iti na ca byañjanena ālopam atināma iti
translated: He eats the curry only as a flavoring for the rice, and he doesn’t fill up on it.

original: Dvattikkhattuṁ kho bhavaṁ gotamo mukhe ālopaṁ samparivattetvā ajjhoharati;
analyzed: dvattikkhattum khalu bhavam gotamaḥ mukhe ālopam samparivattetvā ajjhoharati
translated: He chews his food thoroughly before swallowing.🔽He eats without distinguishing tastes, and he doesn’t pick and choose.

translated: He doesn’t eat too much to his fill, so as to indulge his desire for a pleasant feeling.🔽He eats only to maintain and nourish his body, to protect it, and to assist in the spiritual life.🔽He has a sense of moderation in accepting drinks and foods.🔽He has a sense of moderation in the four requisite items.

original: athāparaṁ ālopaṁ upanāmeti.
analyzed: atha aparam ālopam upanāma iti
translated: He has a sense of moderation in accepting invitations.

original: Rasapaṭisaṁvedī kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo āhāraṁ āhāreti, no ca rasarāgapaṭisaṁvedī.🔽Aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṁ kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo āhāraṁ āhāreti—
analyzed: rasa paṭisavedī kho pana saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ āhāram āhāreti no ca rasa rāga paṭisavedī 🔽aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam kho pana so bhavam gotamaḥ āhāram āhāra iti
translated: He has a sense of moderation in accepting robes, alms-food, dwellings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

original: neva davāya, na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya, yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā🔽yāpanāya, vihiṁsūparatiyā brahmacariyānuggahāya: ‘iti purāṇañca vedanaṁ paṭihaṅkhāmi
analyzed: na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya yāvat eva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā  yāpanāya brahmacariya anuggahāya iti purāṇam ca vedanam paṭihaṅkhāmi
translated: not for fun, for intoxication, for getting high, for beautification, or for adornment, but only to keep this body going,

original: navañca vedanaṁ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro cā’ti.
analyzed: navam ca vedanam na uppādessāmi yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajja tā ca phāsu vihāraḥ ca ati
translated: to avoid harming it, to help with spiritual life, thinking: ‘Thus I shall terminate old feelings without arousing new feelings, and I will be healthy, blameless, and comfortable.’

original: So bhuttāvī pattodakaṁ paṭiggaṇhanto na pattaṁ unnāmeti, na pattaṁ onāmeti; na pattaṁ sannāmeti, na pattaṁ vināmeti.🔽So pattodakaṁ paṭiggaṇhāti nātithokaṁ nātibahuṁ.
analyzed: saḥ bhuttāvī patta udakam paṭiggaṇhantaḥ na pattam unnāmeti na pattam onāmeti na pattam sannāmeti na pattam vināmeti  saḥ patta udakam paṭiggaṇhāti na atithokam na atibahu
translated: When he has eaten and is taking the water for his bowl, he does not tip the bowl up too high or too low, nor does he tip it away or towards himself.🔽He takes the water for his bowl neither too little nor too much.

original: So na khulukhulukārakaṁ pattaṁ dhovati, na samparivattakaṁ pattaṁ dhovati, na pattaṁ
analyzed: saḥ na khulukhulukārakam pattam dhovati na samparivattakam pattam dhovati na patta
translated: He does not wash his bowl with a sloshing sound, nor does he wash it by turning it over.🔽He does not put his bowl on the ground and then wash his hands.

original: bhūmiyaṁ nikkhipitvā hatthe dhovati; hatthesu dhotesu patto dhoto hoti, patte dhote hatthā dhotā honti.
analyzed: bhūmiyam nikkhipitvā hatthe dhovati hatthesu dhotesu pattaḥ dhotaḥ hoti patte dhote hatthāḥ dhotāḥ honti
translated: When his hands are washed, his bowl is washed. When his bowl is washed, his hands are washed.

original: So pattodakaṁ chaḍḍeti nātidūre nāccāsanne, na ca vicchaḍḍayamāno.
analyzed: saḥ patta udakam chaḍḍeti na atidūre na at ca āsanne na ca vicchaḍḍayamānaḥ
translated: He discards the water for his bowl neither too far nor too near, nor does he discard it with contempt.

original: So bhuttāvī na pattaṁ bhūmiyaṁ nikkhipati nātidūre nāccāsanne, na ca anatthiko pattena hoti, na ca ativelānurakkhī pattasmiṁ.🔽So bhuttāvī muhuttaṁ tuṇhī nisīdati, na ca anumodanassa kālamatināmeti.
analyzed: saḥ bhuttāvī na pattam bhūmiyam nikkhipati na atidūre na acca āsanne na ca anatthiko pattena hoti na ca ativelā anurakkhī pattasmi  saḥ bhuttāvī muhuttam tuṇhī nisīdati na ca anumodanassa kālam atināmeti
translated: After the meal, he doesn’t put away the bowl-washing water on the ground, not too far or too near, and he doesn’t stand in need of the bowl-washing water. He doesn’t over-protect the bowl.🔽After the meal, he sits in silence for a while, not urging the assembly to dismiss.

original: So bhuttāvī anumodati, na taṁ bhattaṁ garahati, na aññaṁ bhattaṁ paṭikaṅkhati;
analyzed: so bhuttāvī anumodati na tam bhattam garahati na aññam bhattam paṭikaṅkhati
translated: After the meal, he gives a teaching, not criticizing or disparaging anyone else’s meal.

original: aññadatthu dhammiyā kathāya taṁ parisaṁ sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṁseti.
analyzed: aññadatthu dhammiyā kathāya tam parisam sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaseti
translated: He instructs, urges, rouses, and encourages the assembly with a talk on Dhamma.

original: So taṁ parisaṁ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṁsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamati.
analyzed: saḥ tam parisam dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahasetvā uṭṭhāya āsanā pakkamati
translated: Having instructed, urged, roused, and encouraged the assembly with a talk on Dhamma, he gets up from his seat and leaves.

original: So nātisīghaṁ gacchati, nātisaṇikaṁ gacchati, na ca muccitukāmo gacchati;
analyzed: saḥ na ati sīgham gacchati na ati saṇikam gacchati na ca muccitu kāmaḥ gacchati
translated: He doesn’t walk too fast or too slow, and he doesn’t walk as if he were in a hurry to get away.

original: na ca tassa bhoto gotamassa kāye cīvaraṁ accukkaṭṭhaṁ hoti na ca accokkaṭṭhaṁ, na ca kāyasmiṁ allīnaṁ na ca kāyasmā apakaṭṭhaṁ;
analyzed: na ca tassa bhoto gotamassa kāye cīvaram accukkaṭṭham hoti na ca accokkaṭṭha na ca kāyasmin allīnam na ca kāyasmai apakaṭṭha
translated: The robe on his body is neither too high nor too low on his body, neither too loose nor too tight on his body.

original: na ca tassa bhoto gotamassa kāyamhā vāto cīvaraṁ apavahati;
analyzed: na ca tassa bhoto gotamassa vātaḥ cīvaram apavahati
translated: and the wind does not blow his outer robe off his body;

original: na ca tassa bhoto gotamassa kāye rajojallaṁ upalimpati.
analyzed: na ca tassa bhoto gotamassa kāye rajaḥ jallam upalimpati
translated: and dust and dirt do not settle on his body.

original: So ārāmagato nisīdati paññatte āsane. Nisajja pāde pakkhāleti;
analyzed: saḥ ārāma gataḥ nisīdati paññatte āsane nisajja pāde pakkhāleti
translated: When he has gone to the monastery and sat down on the seat prepared for him, he washes his feet,

original: na ca so bhavaṁ gotamo pādamaṇḍanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
analyzed: na ca saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ pāda maṇḍana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ viharati
translated: and he does not live devoted to the practice of having his feet washed.

original: So pāde pakkhāletvā nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.

original: Yathāparisaṁ kho pana so bhavaṁ gotamo sarena viññāpeti, na cassa bahiddhā parisāya ghoso niccharati.

translated: We saw the Master Gotama walking, we saw him standing, we saw him🔽entering a village for alms, we saw him sitting in a place covered with grass,

translated: When this was said, the brahmin Brahmayu rose from his seat, and after arranging his upper robe on one shoulder, he extended his hands in reverential salutation towards the Lord, and uttered this exclamation three times:

translated: “The recluse Gotama, the son of the Sakyans who went forth from a Sakyan clan,

original: viharati maghadevaambavane.

translated: He has now come to Mithila and is staying in the Mango Grove of Maghadeva.

translated: Now a good report of Master Gotama has been spread to this effect:🔽‘That Blessed One is accomplished, fully enlightened, perfect in true knowledge and conduct, sublime, knower of worlds, incomparable leader of persons to be tamed, teacher of gods and humans, enlightened, blessed.’

original: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.

original: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī”ti.

original: Atha kho mithileyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā🔽appekacce bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu; appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṁ

translated: Then the brahmin householders of Mithilā went to the Buddha.🔽Some bowed and sat down to one side.

translated: Some announced their name and clan in the Buddha’s presence and sat down to one side.🔽Some remained silent as they sat down to one side.

original: Assosi kho brahmāyu brāhmaṇo: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito mithilaṁ anuppatto, mithilāyaṁ viharati maghadevaambavane”ti.

translated: The brahmin Brahmayu heard that the ascetic Gotama, the son of the Sakyans who had gone forth from the Sakyan clan, had arrived at Mithila and was staying in the mango grove of Maghādeva.

original: Atha kho brahmāyu brāhmaṇo sambahulehi sāvakehi saddhiṁ yena maghadevaambavanaṁ tenupasaṅkami.

translated: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, the brahmin rose from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.

original: Atha kho brahmāyu brāhmaṇo tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṁ khādanīyaṁ bhojanīyaṁ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṁ ārocāpesi:🔽“kālo, bho gotama, niṭṭhitaṁ bhattan”ti.
analyzed: atha kho brahmāyu brāhmaṇaḥ tassāḥ rattiyāḥ accayena sake nivesane paṇītam khādanīyam bhojanīyam paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālam ārocāpesi  kālaḥ bho gotama niṭṭhitam bhattanti
translated: The following morning the brahmin had various kinds of fine food prepared in his own house. He then had the Buddha informed that the meal was ready.

original: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena brahmāyussa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghena.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya yena brahmāyussa brāhmaṇassa nivesanam tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhim bhikkhu saṅghena
translated: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and went to the brahmin’s house, where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.

original: Atha kho brahmāyu brāhmaṇo sattāhaṁ buddhappamukhaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
analyzed: atha kho brahmāyu brāhmaṇaḥ sattāham buddha ppamukham bhikkhu saṅgham paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi
translated: Then for a week the brahmin Brahmayu served and satisfied the community of monks, with the Buddha at its head, with his own hands with excellent staple and non-staple food.

original: Atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena videhesu cārikaṁ pakkāmi.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena videhesu cārikam pakkāmi
translated: Then, with the passing of seven days, the Blessed One set out to wander in the country of the Videhans.

original: Atha kho brahmāyu brāhmaṇo acirapakkantassa bhagavato kālamakāsi.
analyzed: atha kho brahmāyuḥ brāhmaṇaḥ acira pakkantassa bhagavataḥ kālam akāsi
translated: Then, not long after the Blessed One had departed, the brahmin Brahmayu died.🔽Then a large number of monks went to the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, they sat down at one side

original: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: atha kho sambahulāḥ bhikkhū yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdisu ekamantam nisinnāḥ kho te bhikkhū bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: and said to him:

original: “brahmāyu, bhante, brāhmaṇo kālaṅkato.
analyzed: brahmāyu bhante brāhmaṇaḥ kālaṅkato
translated: “Venerable sir, the brahmin Brahmayu has died.

original: Tassa kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo”ti?
analyzed: tassa kā gati kaḥ abhisamparāyaḥ ti
translated: What is his destination, what his future state?”

original: “Paṇḍito, bhikkhave, brahmāyu brāhmaṇo paccapādi dhammassānudhammaṁ, na ca maṁ dhammādhikaraṇaṁ vihesesi.
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ bhikkhave brahmāyu brāhmaṇaḥ paccapādi dhammassa anudhamma na ca mama dhamma adhikaraṇam vihesesi
translated: “Monks, the brahmin Brahmayu was wise, he practiced in accordance with the Dhamma and did not trouble me in the interpretation of the Dhamma.

original: Brahmāyu, bhikkhave, brāhmaṇo pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti, tattha parinibbāyī, anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā”ti.
analyzed: brahmāyu bhikkhave brāhmaṇaḥ pañcannam orambhāgiyānam sayojanānam parikkhayā opapātikaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokāti
translated: With the destruction of the five lower fetters, the brahmin Brahmāyu was one who attains final knowledge early in this very life. He was one who attains final knowledge at the time of death. He was one who attains final knowledge early. He was one who attains final knowledge at the time of death. He was one who attains final knowledge without exertion. He was one who attains final knowledge with exertion. He was bound upstream, heading toward the Akaniṭṭha realm.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: That is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.🔽Brahmāyusuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ paṭhamaṁ.
analyzed: attamanāḥ te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandunti 🔽brahmāyusuttam niṭṭhitam paṭhama
translated: The bhikkhus were satisfied and delighted in the Blessed One’s words.
